channel.title: Great job offer!
channel.description:
Today, I received this e-mail, containing a once in a lifetime opportunity(!!!):
The ELS, [b]american[/b] company known worldwide as a first class [b]diller[/b] for luxury goods, is currently [b]hiring for[/b] administrative assistant/sales support representatives [b]in Netherlands[/b]. [b]This position is originally home-based[/b], so good for those looking for a [b]schedule flexible[/b] and extra cash.
Is this a new kind of e-mail scam? Further on, they ask me to send them my CV. Just looking at the spelling and grammar used in the e-mail, you can understand that this is a big pile of bullshit. But what can they do with my CV?

item.title: Great job offer!
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

R.I.P RSC:

Just bolded the most apparent errors, which make it even clearer that it’s a scam. What bothers me though is the fact that I got this e-mail on my school mail address, with which I’ve never ever sent an e-mail with. How is it possible that a 3rd party found it?

I got endless spam, pharmaceuticals, (fake) job offerings, offers of fake degrees, etc to my uni email literally straight away after it was created. The reason is, most universities have nice but vulnerable email setups.

So at manchester I had my personal email which was greenyABC@manchester.ac.uk

However, you could also email students@manchester.ac.uk, firstyears@manchester.ac.yj (obs secondyears@ if i was a second year, and so on). Then there was departmental so, csstudents@manchester.ac.uk

There was probably even more, but you can see how advertisers don’t actually need your email address, they just need one of the ones that redirects to thousands of students.

I’m surprised they never installed a decent mail filter

item.title: Great job offer!
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Moparisthebest:

I guess it’s possible that they could use all the information on your CV/resume to steal your identity, try to verify information about them first.

I’m not going to respond at all. I know this is a fake. Perhaps you are right about the identity theft.

[quote=“Greeny, post:6, topic:387792”]I get these all the time, they offer you say £1500/ per month, job from home but you need to invest £xxx to start.

So it’s a silly scam, because what kind of employer asks you for money.[/quote]

In the e-mail they don’t ask for any money, but they do offer €1700,- a month plus 5% bonus of the revenue I generate.

I might as well post the entire e-mail:

Good day!

The ELS, american company known worldwide as a first class diller for luxury goods, is currently hiring for administrative assistant/sales support representatives in Netherlands. This position is originally home-based, so good for those looking for a schedule flexible and extra cash.

The whole point of the vacancy is maintaining sales support duties daily within Netherlands. The tasks may vary from daily to weekly and to monthly.

If pointing out the obligations those will be:

  • Maintain Sales Department operation processes, supporting current projects, handling the orders and reporting on duties performed.
  • Corresponding with customers and other departments.
    The privilege of the position is an opportunity to create your own convenient schedule. You can do either: pert time or full time. Though in any case it will be Monday through Friday, and for a part time it will be 3 hours a day.

Payroll: For a part-time option a pay is 1.700EUR per month + bonus, which is 5% of the amount of transaction completed.

As it is a home-based position all communications between an employee and a company will be performed on-line. The necessary assistance will be fulfilled over the phone, if there is a need in such.
Necessary knowledge and equipment: It was agreed that a successful candidate should posses a good knowledge on English, Excel and good level of motivation. And as for the equipment it.s a PC and stable internet connection.

An employee needs not to involve his or her personal funds into business activity of a company. A company covers all the expenses that have appeared in relation to fulfilling obligations under the position mentioned.

In order to process with applying for the position mentioned please forward your CV to Carol.Moss@ELS-jobs.com

We’d really appreciate if you specified is it a part-time or a full-time job you are looking for. We.ll contact you at the same e-mail if you meet our requirements. The next step will be us offering you to get on a trial period for one month. The trial period means payroll and total support for an employee so he or she could learn new skills and complete tasks successfully. Upon termination of a trial period the cooperation can be continued or terminated on both sides. Base salary will be increased in future. Please, forward your questions to Carol.Moss@ELS-jobs.com

Best wishes
ELS Team

Just bolded the most apparent errors, which make it even clearer that it’s a scam. What bothers me though is the fact that I got this e-mail on my school mail address, with which I’ve never ever sent an e-mail with. How is it possible that a 3rd party found it?
